chapter.title: Parsing and segmenting structured messages
chapter.para: The filters and default macros of syslog-ng work well on the headers and metainformation of the log messages, but are rather limited when processing the content of the messages. Parsers can segment the content of the messages into name-value pairs, and these names can be used as user-defined macros. Subsequent filtering or other type of processing of the message can use these custom macros to refer to parts of the message. Parsers are global objects most often used together with filters and rewrite rules.
The &abbrev; application provides the following possibilities to parse the messages, or parts of the messages:

listitem.para: By default, &abbrev; parses every message as a syslog message. To disable message parsing, use the flags(no-parse) option of the source. To explicitly parse a message as a syslog message, use the syslog parser. For details, see .
To segment a message into columns using a CSV-parser, see .
To segment a message consisting of whitespace or comma-separated key=value pairs (for example, Postfix log messages), see .
To parse a specially-formatted date or timestamp, see .
To write a custom parser in Python, see .
To identify and parse the messages using a pattern database, see .
